list.expr: sum(vm_app_version{job=~"$job", instance=~"$instance"}) by(short_version) unless (sum(vm_app_version{job=~"$job", instance=~"$instance"} offset $__interval) by(short_version))
list.name: version

description: Overview for VictoriaMetrics vmagent v1.117.0 or higher

panels.description: Shows the rate of [samples](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victoriametrics/keyconcepts/#raw-samples) scraped from configured targets.
panels.title: Samples scraped/s

panels.description: Shows the number of targets scraped per second.
panels.title: Targets scraped/s

panels.description:
Persistent queue size shows size of pending samples in bytes which hasn't been flushed to remote storage yet. 
Increasing of value might be a sign of connectivity issues. In such cases, vmagent starts to flush pending data on disk with attempt to send it later once connection is restored.
panels.title: Persistent queue size

panels.description: Total number of available CPUs for selected vmagents.
panels.title: Available CPU

panels.description: Shows the rate of ingested [samples](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victoriametrics/keyconcepts/#raw-samples)
panels.title: Samples ingested/s

panels.description:
Shows total number of all configured scrape targets in state `up` or `down`.

See `http://vmagent-host:8429/targets` to get list of all targets.
panels.title: Scrape targets

panels.description: Shows number of generated  error messages in  logs over last 30m. Non-zero value may be a sign of connectivity or misconfiguration errors.
panels.title: Log messages (30m)

panels.description: Total size of available memory for selected vmagents.
panels.title: Available memory

panels.description:
Shows in/out [samples](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victoriametrics/keyconcepts/#raw-samples) rate including push and pull models. 

The out-rate could be different to in-rate because of replication or additional timeseries added by vmagent for every scraped target.

Click on the line and choose Drilldown to show CPU usage per instance
panels.title: Samples rate ($instance)

panels.description:
Shows the persistent queue size of pending samples in bytes >2MB which hasn't been flushed to remote storage yet. 

Increasing of value might be a sign of connectivity issues. In such cases, vmagent starts to flush pending data on disk with attempt to send it later once connection is restored.

Remote write URLs are hidden by default but might be unveiled once `-remoteWrite.showURL` is set to true.

Click on the line and choose Drilldown to show the persistent queue size per instance.
panels.title: Persistent queue size  ($instance) to ($url)

panels.description: Shows the rate of logging the messages by their level. Unexpected spike in rate is a good reason to check logs.
panels.title: Logging rate

panels.description:
Shows rate of dropped [samples](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victoriametrics/keyconcepts/#raw-samples) from persistent queue. vmagent drops samples from queue if in-memory and on-disk queues are full and it is unable to flush them to remote storage.
The max size of on-disk queue is configured by `-remoteWrite.maxDiskUsagePerURL` flag.
panels.title: Persistent queue dropped rate ($instance)

panels.description: Shows the rate of requests served by vmagent HTTP server.
panels.title: Requests rate  ($instance)

panels.description: Errors rate shows rate for multiple metrics that track possible errors in vmagent, such as network or parsing errors.
panels.title: Errors rate  ($instance)

panels.description:
How much resident memory (RAM) the process is actually using, compared to its allowed container or system limit.

- Good: Below 70% most of the time, maybe spiking a bit under load.
- Bad: Above 90% for more than 5 minutes = risk of out-of-memory (OOM) kill.

Click on the line and choose Drilldown to show memory usage per instance
panels.title: RSS memory % usage ($instance)

panels.description:
Share for memory allocated by the process itself. When memory usage reaches 100% it will be likely OOM-killed.
Safe memory usage % considered to be below 80%

Click on the line and choose Drilldown to show memory usage per instance
panels.title: RSS anonymous memory % usage

panels.description:
CPU pressure based on [Pressure Stall Information](https://docs.kernel.org/accounting/psi.html). Helps troubleshoot high CPU usage or throttling.
Lower is better.

- waiting: The percentage of time at least one task in the process was ready to run (runnable) but couldn't get scheduled on the CPU.
- stalled: The percentage of time all tasks in the process (except idle ones) were unable to get CPU time  a full CPU stall.

If there's a CPU burst, it's normal to see waiting or stalled > 1%. It only becomes a concern if it consistently climbs above 510% and aligns with latency spikes or GC slowdowns.
panels.title: CPU pressure

panels.description:
Shows memory pressure based on [Pressure Stall Information](https://docs.kernel.org/accounting/psi.html).
Lower is better.

- waiting: Time fraction where at least one thread was blocked on memory.
- stalled: Time fraction where every thread was blocked on memory (severe pressure).

If queries slow down and both series spike, the host is likely limited by RAM or I/O throughput.
panels.title: Memory pressure

panels.description:
Shows the number of bytes read/write from the storage layer when vmagent has to buffer data on disk or read already buffered data.

Click on the line and choose Drilldown to show CPU usage per instance
panels.title: Disk writes/reads ($instance)

panels.description:
Shows IO pressure based on [Pressure Stall Information](https://docs.kernel.org/accounting/psi.html).

The lower the better.
panels.title: IO pressure

panels.description:
Network usage shows the bytes rate for data accepted by vmagent and pushed via remotewrite protocol.
Discrepancies are possible because of different protocols used for ingesting, scraping and writing data.
panels.title: Network  usage ($instance)

panels.description:
Shows the percent of CPU spent on garbage collection.

If % is high, then CPU usage can be decreased by changing GOGC to higher values. Increasing GOGC value will increase memory usage, and decrease CPU usage.

Try searching for keyword `GOGC` at https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victoriametrics/troubleshooting/
panels.title: CPU spent on GC ($instance)

panels.description:
Shows the time goroutines have spent in runnable state before actually running. The lower is better.

High values or values exceeding the threshold is usually a sign of            insufficient CPU resources or CPU throttling. 

Verify that service has enough CPU resources. Otherwise, the service could work unreliably with delays in processing.
panels.title: Go scheduling latency

panels.description: Shows the rate of allocations in memory. Sudden increase in allocations would mean increased pressure on Go Garbage Collector and can saturate CPU resources of the application.
panels.title: Memory allocations rate

panels.description:
Panel shows the percentage of open file descriptors in the OS per instance.
Reaching the limit of open files (100%) can cause various issues and must be prevented.

See how to change limits here https://medium.com/@muhammadtriwibowo/set-permanently-ulimit-n-open-files-in-ubuntu-4d61064429a
panels.title: Open FDs usage % ($instance)

panels.description: Shows top 10 jobs by the number of new series registered by vmagent over the 5min range. These jobs generate the most of the churn rate.
panels.title: Top 10 jobs by unique samples

panels.description: Shows top 10 instances by the number of new series registered by vmagent over the 5min range. These instances generate the most of the churn rate.
panels.title: Top 10 instances by unique samples

panels.description: Shows write saturation of the persistent queue. If the threshold of 0.9sec is reached, then the persistent queue is saturated by more than 90% and vmagent won't be able to keep up with flushing data on disk. In this case, consider to decrease load on the vmagent or improve the disk throughput.
panels.title: Persistent queue write saturation ($instance)

panels.description: Shows read saturation of the persistent queue. If the threshold of 0.9sec is reached, then the persistent queue is saturated by more than 90% and vmagent won't be able to keep up with reading data from the disk. In this case, consider to decrease load on the vmagent or improve the disk throughput.
panels.title: Persistent queue read saturation ($instance)

panels.description:
Shows the rate of dropped data blocks in cases when remote storage replies with `400 Bad Request` and `409 Conflict` HTTP responses.

See https://github.com/VictoriaMetrics/VictoriaMetrics/issues/1149
panels.title: Data blocks dropped ($instance) to ($url)

panels.description:
Shows the rate of dropped [samples](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victoriametrics/keyconcepts/#raw-samples) due to relabeling. 
Metric tracks drops for `-remoteWrite.relabelConfig` configuration only.
panels.title: Rows dropped by relabeling ($instance) to ($url)

panels.description: Shows the rate of parsed datapoints from write or scrape requests.
panels.title: Datapoints rate ($instance)

panels.description: Tracks the rate of dropped invalid rows because of errors while unmarshaling write requests. The exact errors messages will be printed in logs.
panels.title: Invalid datapoints rate ($instance)

targets.expr: sum(flag{is_set="true", job=~"$job", instance=~"$instance"}) by(job, instance, name, value)

panels.description: Shows the number of restarts per job. The chart can be useful to identify periodic process restarts and correlate them with potential issues or anomalies. Normally, processes shouldn't restart unless restart was inited by user. The reason of restarts should be figured out by checking the logs of each specific service.
panels.title: Restarts ($job)

panels.description: Shows how many samples were ignored on insertion due to various reasons. See the reason of rejection application logs.
panels.title: Rows ignored for last 1h ($instance)

panels.description: Shows the number of scrapes per second.
panels.title: Scrape rate  ($instance)

panels.description: Shows the number of datapoints scraped per second.
panels.title: Scraped datapoints rate  ($instance)

panels.description: Shows the rate of write requests served by ingestserver (UDP, TCP connections) and HTTP server.
panels.title: Requests rate  ($instance)

panels.description: Shows the rate of rows ingested in vmagent via push protocols.
panels.title: Rows rate  ($instance)

panels.description:
Shows how many concurrent inserts are taking place.

If the number of concurrent inserts hitting the `limit` or is close to the `limit` constantly - it might be a sign of a resource shortage.

 If vmagent's CPU usage and remote write connection saturation are at normal level, it might be that `-maxConcurrentInserts` cmd-line flag need to be increased.
panels.title: Concurrent inserts ($instance)

panels.description: Shows the rate of write errors in ingestserver (UDP, TCP connections) and HTTP server.
panels.title: Error rate  ($instance)

panels.description:
Shows the number of matched samples by the aggregation rule. 

The more samples is matched, the more work this aggregation rule does. The matching rule is specified via `match` param.

See more details in [stream aggregation config](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victoriametrics/stream-aggregation/#stream-aggregation-config).
panels.title: Matched samples ($instance)

panels.description:
The rate of ignored samples during aggregation. 
Stream aggregation will drop samples with NaN values, or samples with too old timestamps. See https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victoriametrics/stream-aggregation/#ignoring-old-samples
panels.title: Ignored samples ($instance)

panels.description:
Shows the number of produced samples by the aggregation rule. 

Number of produced samples depend on params like `by`, `without`, `interval`, etc.

See more details in [stream aggregation config](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victoriametrics/stream-aggregation/#stream-aggregation-config).
panels.title: Produced samples ($instance)
Flush timeouts ($instance)

panels.description:
Shows the max lag between samples timestamps within one batch passed to the aggregation input.

Lower is better.

Too high lag or lag exceeding the interval might be a sign that data was delayed before aggregation or resource insufficiency on aggregator. Samples with high lag may affect accuracy of aggregation.

See https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victoriametrics/stream-aggregation/#ignoring-old-samples
panels.title: Samples lag 0.99 quantile ($instance)

panels.description:
The 99th percentile of avg flush duration for the aggregated data. 

Smaller is better.

Aggregation can produce incorrect results ff flush duration exceeds configured deduplication interval. See "Flush Timeouts" panel.
panels.title: Dedup flush duration 0.99 quantile ($instance)

panels.description:
Shows the size of Label Compressor in number of entries.

Labels compressor encodes label-value pairs during aggregation to optimise memory usage. It is expected for its size to grow with time and to reset on vmagent restarts.

Rapid spikes in Label compressor size might be a sign of significant changes in labels of received samples.
panels.title: Labels compressor ($instance)

panels.description:
Shows the rate of requests to configured remote write endpoints by url and status code.

Remote write URLs are hidden by default but might be unveiled once `-remoteWrite.showURL` is set to true.
panels.title: Requests rate ($instance) to ($url)

panels.description: Shows the global rate for number of written bytes via remote write connections.
panels.title: Bytes write rate ($instance)

panels.description:
Shows requests retry rate by url. Number of retries is unlimited but protected with delays up to 1m between attempts.

Remote write URLs are hidden by default but might be unveiled once `-remoteWrite.showURL` is set to true.
panels.title: Retry rate ($instance) to ($url)

panels.description: Shows current number of established connections to remote write endpoints.
panels.title: Connections ($instance)

panels.description:
Shows the current limit usage of unique series over an hourly period. Vmagent will start to drop series once the limit is reached.

Please note, panel will be blank if `remoteWrite.maxHourlySeries` is not set.
panels.title: Hourly series limit

panels.description:
Shows saturation of every connection to remote storage. If the threshold of 90% is reached, then the connection is saturated (busy or slow) by more than 90%, so vmagent won't be able to keep up and can start buffering data. 

This usually means that `-remoteWrite.queues` command-line flag must be increased in order to increase the number of connections per each remote storage.
panels.title: Remote write connection saturation ($instance)

panels.description:
Shows the current limit usage of unique series over a daily period. Vmagent will start to drop series once the limit is reached.

Please note, panel will be blank if `remoteWrite.maxDailySeries` is not set.
panels.title: Daily series limit

options.content: Drilldown row is used by other panels on the dashboard to show more detailed metrics per-instance.

panels.description:
Shows the used memory (resident).
The application's performance will significantly degrade when memory usage is close to 100%.
panels.title: RSS memory usage ($instance)

panels.description:
Shows the persistent queue size of pending samples in bytes which hasn't been flushed to remote storage yet. 

Increasing of value might be a sign of connectivity issues. In such cases, vmagent starts to flush pending data on disk with attempt to send it later once connection is restored.

Remote write URLs are hidden by default but might be unveiled once `-remoteWrite.showURL` is set to true.
panels.title: Persistent queue size  ($instance) to ($url)

panels.description:
Shows in/out samples rate including push and pull models. 

The out-rate could be different to in-rate because of replication or additional timeseries added by vmagent for every scraped target.
panels.title: Samples rate ($instance)

panels.description: Shows the number of bytes read/write from the storage layer when vmagent has to buffer data on disk or read already buffered data.
panels.title: Disk writes/reads ($instance)

panels.description:
Shows an estimated time until a persistent queue reaches its disk usage limit for a given instance and -remoteWrite.url.

The ETA is shown only when the pending queue size is actively growing, which typically indicates that remote write cannot keep up with ingestion (e.g. the remote endpoint is slow or unavailable).

Once the disk usage limit is reached, newly ingested metrics will be dropped.

The estimation is approximate and may fluctuate due to short-term changes in the queue growth rate.

targets.expr:
(sum(vm_persistentqueue_free_disk_space_bytes{job=~"$job", instance=~"$instance"}) by (job, instance, path))
/
(sum(deriv(vm_persistentqueue_bytes_pending{job=~"$job", instance=~"$instance"}[1m])) by (job, instance, path) > 0)
* on(job, instance, path) group_left(url)
(vmagent_remotewrite_pending_data_bytes{job=~"$job", instance=~"$instance", url=~"$url"}*0 + 1)

panels.title: Persistent queue Full ETA ($instance)

title: VictoriaMetrics - vmagent
